page.title: 18THE SHOVEL WORKS
page.content: The original Richard Carter shovel works was built in 1740. It covers over an acre of land and employs 17 people. Ever since 1740 it has been in the Carter family. When it was opened other plants were opened but they have all shut down since then. Around 12,000 shovels, 8,000 handles and about 12,000 hammer and axe shafts are made a month, all of which are sold. During the miners strike the sale of shovels dropped, as 75% are sold to the NCB. All parts of the shovels are made at the works. The main materials used to make shovels are steel and aluminium. The shovel works do their own deliveries as long as they can get there and back in a day. Otherwise they take the deliveries to Birmingham or Carlisle so the next leg of the journey can be done. Also the works send exports to Canada and Nigeria.
